top_comment.text:
Hi i suffer with depression and some days and weeks or months it gets the 
better of me, ive taken my depression out on myself,friends family and also 
my girlfriend and tbh in surprised shes still with me after everything ive 
put her through, most weeks i dont go into college which ino is bad but my 
depression gets the best of me i hardly eat at times because of it, im 
covered in scars and because of the scars i hate my body, everything you 
have said in this video has made me realise that i should start turning for 
help and to stop fighting for this on my own and to not be scared to ask 
for a little help , thank you sooo much lucy for making this video you 
inspire me soo much ﻿
top_comment.author: Kiera Bates (kizzy)

comments.text:
It's really good you have someone to support you. You could try talking to 
a friend or family member as well if there is anyone you really trust and 
think could help. I went to my doctor and was on anti depressants for a 
while which didn't help me at all, but they do work for some people. It was 
only when I spoke to my line manager and got counselling through work that 
things got better for me. It's about finding the right thing for you though 
and that can mean trying a few different things before something works. My 
friend suffers from depression as well and finds that mindfulness 
techniques help her - there's lots of books and stuff online about it. Or 
there's online CBT courses...
asking for help is hard and it took me a really long time but the more 
people you have supporting you the easier it is. Also find out as much as 
you can about it and what options you have in terms of help (knowledge is 
power!)
Sorry that ended up being so long! hope some of it helps
comments.author: bluepixie15

comments.text:
thanks hun it means a lot you saying this but I guess I just never have the 
confidence to ask for help form people and that's what I find hard because 
I still haven't asked for help but my girlfriend is the only person im 
getting help from
comments.author: Kiera Bates (kizzy)

comments.text:
Hi Kiera, just wanted to say keep fighting, it does get better. Asking for 
help can be hard but it can make a massive difference. I've been in 
counselling for a year after suffering with depression for about 8 years. I 
still get the odd bad day and occasionally a bad week but its nothing like 
it used to be. I am happier now than I have ever been. It sounds like you 
have a great girlfriend (bit jealous!) and she really cares about you. 
Also, I used to hate my scars but now I actually kinda like them, they 
remind me that even though it was really bad, I kept going and got through 
it. I hope you find the help you need and things get better for you.
comments.author: bluepixie15

comments.author: Nic Mac

top_comment.text:
I had a major setback when I got diagnosed with cancer at 16. Friends and 
family helped me pullet through, and although I relapsed an additional two 
times I learned something I would not live without: happiness is a choice. 
Not like, dude if you’re sad just “choose” to be happy. You need to 
surround yourself with things you like. I was privileged enough to be able 
to stay in school and am now in the process of becoming a lawyer. They way 
I see the world is way different from my peers. I love long showers. I 
appreciate long walks way more than I used to. Everyday things make me 
really excited. Because I made a choice to look at the smaller things. And 
I really really can’t explain how important food is. Eating proper food and 
being healthy is the best thing you can ever do of yourself. And that does 
include chocolate, ice cream, chips and all the other glorious food out 
there. Be good to yourself. ﻿
top_comment.author: Cathrine Juhl

comments.text:
I'm moved by your story. Hope you're doing alright today. Hazelnut butter 
sounds really soothing and lovely too! Sending you the best thoughts from 
Denmark! Keep being awesome!
comments.author: Cathrine Juhl

comments.text:
I completely agree. I have a serious autoimmune disease and also feel that 
I choose to be happy on a daily basis. I chose to keep a positive attitude 
and not sit and wallow in the things I can't do anymore. I choose to focus 
on what I can enjoy. At this very moment is the lovely soothing feeling of 
hazelnut body butter over my whole body, making my skin soft and 
comfortable. It's the simple things.
comments.author: aimgrrrl

top_comment.text:
Thank you for this Lucy. The point you made about finding happiness in 
smaller things is actually something I came to realize on my own recently. 
Not every moment in your life is going to be as big as say, graduating, 
getting a new car, getting a new good job, meeting your special someone, 
etc. Most days (speaking for myself here ) are just like take-out food and 
Netflix (for example), and that's perfectly okay. I stopped comparing what 
I've done so far with what everyone else has done/is doing, and just enjoy 
being myself and doing things my own way. I found I was a lot happier doing 
that. Also hope this makes some kind of sense because I end up typing so 
fast that my brain hasn't finished processing what I actually want to say 
and sometimes it doesn't come out right (derp) >.>﻿
top_comment.author: lmrelm

comments.text: I agree,
comments.author: Cammie Gelangre

comments.text:
Either you rotate around other people's lives and you become a "satellite" 
or you drive Life to turn around your own center, and you become another, 
individual little *source of Life*... this is true even in Physics! :-)
comments.author: Dmh Frou

comments.text:
You're right. We should not compare us to others, we all have different 
paths to follow.
comments.author: Amanda Pina

comments.text:
I agree with your comment muchly! In my case, so many of my friends are so 
successful in their career, whereas I am less career-orientated (or 
oriented if your 'murican) and for a long time I wanted so much to be like 
them, applying for jobs that were way out of my league and then sliding 
into a depression as I was rejected over and over again. It's important to 
love who YOU are and not strive to be what others tell you is 'successful'

comments.author: lmrelm

captions.text:
So, I get a lot of question on
Tumblr about being

happy. And, I
do my best to answer as many as

I can but sometimes
it's just not possible, and so

I thought I would just make a
video

I want to make it quite clear,
very quickly, that this video

is not depression and it's not
about curing

depression or anything like
that. And there's a big

difference between
being sad and being depressed

and I'm sure you all know that.
But I wanted to make that clear.

So, I'd like to start by saying
that

it's okay to be sad.
Human beings are made up of

this vast
intricate, multi-faceted

spectrum of
feeling and thoughts and ideas

and emotions, and it's
virtually impossible, in fact

it's literally impossible,
to be happy all the time. You'd

have to be
not human. This brings me onto

the fact that happiness
is not something that is like a

destination.
You don't just arrive at

happiness and unpack
your bags. Happiness isn't

something that lasts forever.
The same way sadness isn't

something that lasts forever.
And it's something that you

will feel throughout your
life not just for one extended

period of time.
In the words of Queens of the

Stone Age, "Go With the
Flow." My second point is

something that I have
done my whole life, and it's

taken me a long time to realize
that it's probably not the best

way
to deal with things. And that

is that when you are sad
it's so easy to want to

wallow in that sadness. And, I
am like

the number one culprit of this.
When I'm feeling sad, for

whatever reason,
I will stay sad for hours,

even days, even weeks, because
of one thing,

or a few things. As much as
it's okay to be sad,

it's important to not let that
take over

your life or your day or your
week. If

you're feeling sad and you want
to lie in your bed and watch

Netflix and eat take out food,
that fine, but

say like "Oh, in an hour I'm
going to get up and I'm going

to go for a walk."
You have to pick yourself up

and keep
going, no matter how it can be,

because it's so easy
to just get stuck in a rut. My

next point leading on
from that, I guess, is that you

should try not to let
the smaller things bother you.

I am very guilty of letting one
bad thing

ruin the rest of my day. So if
I wake up in the

morning and I drop my
hairbrush, or something,

I convince myself that because
of that thing

the rest of my day is going to
be horrible. I feel like that's

a really
unhealthy mindset to have,

because you start looking for
things that prove your point

right
if that makes sense. So, if

you're like "Oh great,
well, this has happened. The

rest of my day is going to be
terrible now."

You start expecting terrible
things to happen. And I guess

that
is just a reflection of what

life is.
It's like a roller coaster to

be cheesy about it.
This brings me on to the

subject of
self-care. And, I found a

really nice
quote, actually, on Tumblr, but

it sort of
comes from that phrase, "Your

body is a temple."
I'm going to read this quote

straight off my phone, and
it says "Your body is not a

temple.
Temples can be destroyed and

desecrated.
Your body is a forest, thick

canopies of maple trees and
sweet

scented wild flowers sprouting
in the underwood. You will grow

back over and over, no matter
how badly

you are devastated. That person
that you are

is sacred and special and
unique. You need to make

sure that those things stay
close to

you. And so by self-care, I
mean that you need to do

what is good your mindset, or
your body or

both. I don't mean go out and
get drunk. Although

as fun as fun that can be it's
probably not going to best for

you in the long run.
Because the body you have is

the only body you're ever
going to have, unless you like-

change arms with someone, you
know, that's

very likely. I mean taking a
nice bath or

going for a walk or watching a
good film. As a sort of tangent,

to that that I do feel like food
in general - I know I talk

about food a lot - it's been
proven

that eating things like leafy
greens

and fish and red meat or
anything with protein in it

if you're a vegetarian, are
generally going to help to

lighten your mood.
Food is going to help

equal out your blood sugar
levels. It's going to help your

brain release the
chemical, serotonin, which is

the "happiness chemical."
By all means, eat the pizza and

the cake and the chocolate, or
whatever,

but also maybe think about
making yourself a nice

smoothie or a soup or something
that's going to have some sort

of
nutritional value or energy to

it.
I know that chocolate has

energy to it, but fruits and
vegetables

have energy that will last
longer. Lastly, I want to

encourage you to
try and find happiness in the

smaller things.
You can find happiness in a new

job,
or a pay raise or an

extravagant trip to Paris, or
owning a Louis Vuitton

suitcase, especially that last
one,

because they are gloriously
crafted. You can find happiness

when you are falling asleep and
you can hear the sound of rain

on your window. And you can
find happiness in a really

nice meal, and you can find
happiness when there's a really

cute
cat coming towards you. Hiii. Hi

Okay.
Did you just give me a kiss?

There's hair in my nose
and in my mouth. You can find

happiness in having a really
nice

nap, or hanging out with your
friends, or the fact

that Crocs are now, no longer
in fashion.

Happiness is achieved when you
stop waiting for it

and you instead choose to live
in

the moment. So stop waiting for
Fridays and stop waiting for

summers and stop waiting for
someone to fall in love with

you,
because those things will

happen, but in the meantime,
enjoy right now.

If all else fails,
cuddle a cat. I love you.
